> As developers we usually have no control over the many
> potential ways that our code could be used, but we do have
> control over how it responds.

This explains much. As a developer, I usually have much control over the
way my code is used. It is only the published interface I don't have
"full control" over - I would agree that for that (hopefully rather
small interface) your definition of robustness applies.

> Actually, I'm sure that contingency is addressed by the
> automotive industry. Now bringing fire near any body of
> petrol is bad, but there are ways to reduce the likelihood of
> a bad thing. Baffles in the tube leading to the petrol tank
> are an example of trying to provide hardware guard conditions.

Afaik they don't guard against putting nitroglycerin into the petrol
tank... ;)

> The project that I am winding up
> now is not life threatening, but because of volume, it does
> need to be very fast and very accurate or the CEO will be
> asking why it is failing to process about 2000 shipments an
> hour! (Not a conversation that I ever want to have!) I still
> think that it's appropriate to "harden" our code to handle
> the unexpected.

Aren't the goals of fast code, robust code (against misuse) and fast
development rather competing?

> This is the concept of "graceful degredation". A web browser
> is a very good example of this .... a lot of web pages have
> awful HTML and yet most of them display acceptably, because
> the browser takes what it's given and does the best it can
> with it. A browser cannot throw an exception, but it can try
> to render what it's given. All software should do the best it
> can with what it's given or when possible reject unacceptable inputs.

Yes, it probably is a good idea to make the external interface rather
robust. But I think that the balance changes for internal communication
of the system.

Regards, Ilja
